channel.title: Job on Christian Internet Resources
channel.description: Recent content in Job on Christian Internet Resources

item.title: Job 1
item.description:
Job Chapter 1

1 Job lived in the land of Uz, a blameless, godly man that respected God and shunned evil. 2He had seven sons and three daughters; 3and owned 7,000 sheep, 3,000 camels, 500 yoke of oxen, 500 female donkeys; and many servants. 4His sons would hold feasts in each other’s houses and invite their three sisters. 5When the feasting days had completed their cycle, Job would consecrate them, getting up early and offering burnt offerings for each one, “Maybe my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts."

item.title: Job 2
item.description:
Job Chapter 2

1 On another day when the sons of God came to present themselves to Yahveh, Satan came with them. 2Yahveh asked him, “Where’d you come from?” “From roaming around in the world.” 3"Have you noticed my servant Job? There’s nobody like him in the world, a blameless, godly man that respects me and shuns evil. He still maintains his integrity, even though you incited me against him to ruin him for no reason." 4"Skin for skin! Everything mortalsm have they’ll give for their life. 5Reach out and touch his flesh and bone, and he’ll curse you to your face." 6"He’s under your authority. Just don’t take his life."

item.title: Job 3
item.description:
Job Chapter 3

1 Afterward Job cursed the day he was born: [2] 3"Perish the day I was born, the night I was conceived.

4 May that be a dark day; let God above not care about it or any light shine on it.

5 Let darkness and gloom claim it, dark clouds cover it, and darkness make it terrifying.

6 Let darkness seize that night; let it not celebrate among the days of the year or be counted among the months.

item.title: Job 4
item.description:
Job Chapter 4

1 Eliphaz the Temanite answered: 2"Will you be offended if someone offers you advice? Who can help speaking up?

3 You’ve admonished many people and encouraged the weak.

4 What you’ve said has helped the tottering stand and weak knees hold firm.

5 But now difficulty has come to you, and you’re impatient and distressed.

6 Isn’t your reverence for God your confidence, and the integrity of your ways your hope? 7"Think now, who ever perished that was innocent? Where were the godly ever destroyed?

item.title: Job 5
item.description:
Job Chapter 5

1 Call out for help now; will anybody answer you? Which of the angels will you turn to?

2 Adversity slays the foolish; anger kills the simpleminded.

3 I’ve seen the foolish taking root and having their progress immediately cursed.

4 Their children are never safe, they’re oppressed in the courts, and there’s nobody to deliver them.

5 The hungry eat up their harvest; briers take over it; schemers are eager to get their wealth;

item.title: Job 6
item.description:
Job Chapter 6

1 Job answered: 2"Oh that my adversity was properly weighed in the balances with my sins!

3 It would outweigh the sand by the seashore; that’s why I’ve been rash.

4 The arrows of the Almighty are piercing me; my spirit is absorbing their poison; God’s terrors are attacking me.

5 Does a wild donkey bray when it has grass? Does an ox bawl over its hay?

item.title: Job 7
item.description:
Job Chapter 7

1 Aren’t people forced into hard labor? Aren’t their days like those of a hired hand?

2 Like a slave panting for shade, like an employee waiting for wages,

3 I’ve been allotted months of emptiness and given restless nights.

4 When I’m in bed, I say, ‘When is morning ever going to get here?’ But night goes on and on, and I toss and turn till dawn.

item.title: Job 8
item.description:
Job Chapter 8

1 Bildad the Shuhite answered: 2"How long will you talk like that? You make your mouth a blustering wind?

3 Does God pervert justice? Does the Almighty twist the truth?

4 When your children sinned against him, he delivered them to the consequences of their sin.

5 If you look for God and beg for mercy from the Almighty,

6 if you’re pure and just, he’ll certainly act on your behalf and restore you to your good position.

item.title: Job 9
item.description:
Job Chapter 9

1 Job answered: 2"I know that’s true, but how can anyone be innocent in God’s sight?

3 If you wanted to dispute with him, you couldn’t answer him once in a thousand times.

4 He’s so wise and powerful; who has ever defied him and succeeded? 5"It’s God that moves mountains; they don’t know it when he overturns them in his anger.

6 He can shake the earth and make its pillars tremble;

item.title: Job 10
item.description:
Job Chapter 10

1 I detest my life; so I’ll fully vent my complaint and speak out of my total frustration.

2 I’ll tell God, ‘Don’t just condemn me; tell me why you’re contending with me.

3 Is it right for you to oppress me, to reject my toil, to look favorably on sinners’ schemes?

4 Do you just have physical eyes and only see like people see?

5 Are your days like a mortal’s, your years like a human’s,

item.title: Job 11
item.description:
Job Chapter 11

1 Zophar the Naamathite answered: 2"Should your barrage of words go unchallenged, and you exonerate yourself by talking a lot?

3 Will your babble shut people up? Will you mock and nobody rebuke you?

4 You claim your beliefs are pure and you’re innocent in God’s presence;

5 but I just wish God would speak out against you

6 and disclose to you the secrets of wisdom, because sound wisdom is not simple; be assured that God doesn’t remember just one part of your sin. 7"Can you find out the deep things of God or probe the limits of the Almighty?

item.title: Job 12
item.description:
Job Chapter 12

1 Job answered: 2"No doubt, you’re the people, and wisdom will die with you!

3 But I’m as smart as you are; I’m not your inferior. Who doesn’t know things like that?

4 I’m a laughingstock to my friends, one who called on God and he answered, a just and blameless man; yet I’m a laughingstock.

5 In the thoughts of people at ease, there’s contempt for disaster; they’re ready to give a shove to those whose feet are slipping.

item.title: Job 13
item.description:
Job Chapter 13

1 I’ve seen that; I’ve heard it and understand it.

2 What you know, I know too; I’m not more ignorant than you. 3"But I’m willing to speak to the Almighty himself; I want to argue with God.

4 You men are smearing me with things that aren’t true; you’re untrained doctors.

5 Oh that you’d just be quiet and show your wisdom that way!

6 Hear me out; listen to what I’m arguing.

item.title: Job 14
item.description:
Job Chapter 14

1 Mortals born of women are short-lived and filled with turmoil.

2 They come out and wither like a flower; they pass away like a shadow and don’t last.

3 You keep your eyes open at them and bring them under your judgment.

4 Who can make unclean into clean? Nobody!

5 Since their days are set, you determine the number of their months and set limits they can’t pass.

item.title: Job 15
item.description:
Job Chapter 15

1 Eliphaz the Temanite answered: 2"Should you answer with empty talk and fill yourself with the east wind?

3 Should you argue with useless speech, with words that do no good?

4 You’re losing reverence for God and hindering meditation in front of him.

5 Your sin is telling you what you say, and you’re choosing misleading language.

6 You condemn yourself; I don’t; you’re testifying against yourself. 7"Were you the first person ever born? Were you brought forth before the hills?

item.title: Job 16
item.description:
Job Chapter 16

1 Job answered: 2"I’ve heard a lot of things like that; you’re miserable comforters.

3 Is there no end to windy words? What’s your problem that you answer me like that?

4 I could talk to you like you’re talking if I was in your place. I could string out words and shake my head at you.

5 Or, I could encourage you so my comfort could lessen your pain. 6"If I speak, it doesn’t take away my pain; if I don’t speak, how much of it goes away?

item.title: Job 17
item.description:
Job Chapter 17

1 My spirit’s broken; my days are snuffed out; people have already dug my grave.

2 Mockers sit around and taunt me to my face. Job 16:18-17:2 3"God, sign a pledge for me; who else will put up security for me?

4 You’ve kept them from understanding; so don’t let them triumph.

5 They inform against their friends to get a share of their property; so let their children pass out from hunger. 6"God has made me a byword among people; I’m someone they spit at.

item.title: Job 18
item.description:
Job Chapter 18

1 Bildad the Shuhite answered: 2"How long will you stumble around for words? Make some sense so we can talk.

3 Why do you treat us like animals? You think we’re stupid?

4 Are you going to tear yourself to pieces in your anger? Are we supposed to leave the world for fear of you? Should ledge rocks quake out of place? 5"The light of the wicked goes out; their flame stops giving light.

item.title: Job 19
item.description:
Job Chapter 19

1 Job answered: 2"How long are you going to torment me and shatter me with a barrage of words?

3 You’ve insulted me ten times over; aren’t you ashamed of treating me wrong?

4 Even if I did make mistakes, that’s on me.

5 If you’re acting superior to me and using my humiliation to argue against me,

6 know that God is the One that’s put me in the wrong and closed his net around me. 7"I cry out, ‘Violence!’ but I don’t get an answer; I call for help, but justice doesn’t come.

item.title: Job 20
item.description:
Job Chapter 20

1 Zophar the Naamathite answered: 2"My thoughts make me answer because I’m in turmoil inside.

3 I’ve listened to your insults, and I’m answering from what I understand.

4 Don’t you know from of old— from the time God put people on earth—

5 that the triumph of sinners is short-lived; the joy of the godless is temporary.

6 Though they’re as tall as the sky, though their heads are in the clouds,

item.title: Job 21
item.description:
Job Chapter 21

1 Job answered: 2"Listen carefully; let this be your consolation.

3 Bear with me; after I’ve spoken, you can mock me.

4 Am I just complaining about people? Why shouldn’t I be impatient?

5 Be appalled at the way I look; put your hand over your mouth in shock.

6 When I think about it, I get scared and shaky.

7 Why do bad people keep on living and become so powerful?

item.title: Job 22
item.description:
Job Chapter 22

1 Eliphaz the Temanite answered. 2"What benefit can a mortal be to God? Aren’t even the wise only useful to themselves?

3 Is the Almighty delighted if you’re good? What good is it to him if you’re perfect?

4 Surely it’s not because you revere him that he’s reproving you, that he’s bringing judgment against you.

5 Isn’t it more likely that you’re sinful, that your sins are endless?

item.title: Job 23
item.description:
Job Chapter 23

1 Job answered: 2"My complaint is still bitter; God’s hand weighs heavily on me despite my groaning.

3 If only I knew where to find him so I could go to his courtroom!

4 I’d present my case and offer my arguments.

5 I’d find out what he’d answer and understand what he’d say.

6 Would he oppose me with his great power? No, he’d listen!

7 Someone godly would be reasoning with him, and my Judge would acquit me permanently. 8"I go east, but he’s not there; I go west, but I can’t find him.

item.title: Job 24
item.description:
Job Chapter 24

1 Why doesn’t the Almighty maintain a regular court schedule for judging? Why do those who know him wait for him in vain?

2 Some remove landmarks, seize flocks and eat them,

3 drive away donkeys that belong to the fatherless, take widows’ oxen for pledges.

4 They run the needy off the road; the poor people have to hide from them.

5 Like wild donkeys in the desert, the poor labor at foraging for food, looking for prey in the wild to feed their children.

item.title: Job 25
item.description:
Job Chapter 25

1 Bildad the Shuhite answered: 2"Dominion and awe belong to God, who establishes order high in his sky.

3 Who can count his troops? Who doesn’t his light rise on?

4 How can anyone be innocent in his presence? How can anyone born of woman be pure?

5 If the moon isn’t bright and the stars aren’t pure to God,

6 how much less people—like maggots, and their offspring—mere worms."

item.title: Job 26
item.description:
Job Chapter 26

1 Job answered: 2"What a help you are to the weak! How you’ve saved arms with no strength!

3 What counsel you’ve given me in my stupidity! What brilliant insight you’ve provided!

4 Who’ve you been talking to? Whose spirit has been speaking through you?! 5"The departed spirits tremble below the water and its inhabitants.

6 Sheol is naked in front of him; Abaddon has no covering before him.

item.title: Job 27
item.description:
Job Chapter 27

1 Job continued his comments: 2"As God lives, who has taken away my rights, the Almighty, who has made me bitter,

3 as long as I’m alive and God’s breath is in me,

4 I won’t speak wickedness or lie.

5 I’ll never concede that you’re right; I’ll defend my integrity till I die.

6 I’ll hold onto my claim about my goodness, and my conscience won’t accuse me for it. 7"May my enemies be like the wicked; may my attackers be like the sinful.

item.title: Job 28
item.description:
Job Chapter 28

1 There’s a mine for silver and a refinery for gold.

2 Iron comes out of the ground, and people can smelt copper.

3 They use a torch in the darkness and go in as far they can, searching for the ore in gloom and deep shadow.

4 They sink mine shafts far from where people live and go down them, dangling on ropes, swinging back and forth.

item.title: Job 29
item.description:
Job Chapter 29

1 Job took up his discourse again: 2"Oh that I could be like I was just a few months ago when God was watching over me,

3 when his lamp shined above my head and I walked through darkness by his light,

4 while I was in the prime of life and his friendship hovered above my tent,

5 when the Almighty was still with me and my children were around me,

item.title: Job 30
item.description:
Job Chapter 30

1 But now people younger than me make fun of me, people whose fathers I wouldn’t let run with my sheep dogs.

2 What good was their strength to me, fellows whose vigor was gone?

3 They were haggard from hunger and want and clawed the dry ground in the wastelands.

4 They picked wild greens from among the bushes and ate the roots of broom shrubs.

item.title: Job 31
item.description:
Job Chapter 31

1 I’ve made a covenant with my eyes not to look with lust at a young woman?

2 What is our portion from God above, our inheritance from the Almighty on high?

3 Isn’t it misfortune for the unjust, disaster for sinners?

4 Doesn’t he see everything I do and count every step I take? 5"If I’ve supposedly conducted myself falsely and tried to deceive,

6 let him weigh me with accurate scales and he’ll find out my integrity.

item.title: Job 32
item.description:
Job Chapter 32

1 The three men stopped replying to Job, because he was certain he was innocent. 2Then Elihu Ben-Barachel the Buzite from the family of Ram, was mad at Job because he’d justified himself to God. 3He was mad at his three friends because they couldn’t answer Job but still condemned him. 4Elihu had waited to speak because they were years older than he was. 5When he saw they didn’t provide an answer, his anger burned inside him. 6So he spoke up. “I’m young and you’re old; so I’ve been reluctant to tell you what I believed.

item.title: Job 33
item.description:
Job Chapter 33

1 But now, Job, listen to what I have to say; hear me out.

2 I’m opening my mouth now; the tongue in my mouth is speaking.

3 What I’m saying expresses my uprightness; my lips declare knowledge sincerely.

4 The Spirit of God has made me; the breath of the Almighty gives me breath.

5 Answer me if you can; state your case; take your stand.

item.title: Job 34
item.description:
Job Chapter 34

1 Elihu continued: 2"Listen, you wise men; pay attention, you that ‘know’;

3 the ear tests words like the palate tastes food.

4 Let’s choose what’s right; let’s determine for ourselves what’s good;

5 because Job has said, ‘I’m good, but God has disregarded my goodness.

6 Should I lie about my goodness? I have a wound that won’t heal, but I haven’t done anything wrong.’

7 Who is like Job that drinks scorn like water,

item.title: Job 35
item.description:
Job Chapter 35

1 Elihu continued: 2"Do you think it’s righteous for you to say you’re upright before God?

3 You say, ‘What advantage will I have? What benefit will I get more than if I’d sinned?’

4 I’ll answer you and your friends.

5 Look at the sky; the clouds are higher than you are.

6 If you’ve sinned, what do you gain against God? if you have lots of sins, what harm are you doing to him?

item.title: Job 36
item.description:
Job Chapter 36

1 Elihu continued: 2"Bear with me a little longer, and I’ll show you what I have to say on God’s behalf.

3 I’ll bring my knowledge from afar and credit goodness to my Maker.

4 What I’m saying is true; I know perfectly well what I’m talking about.

5 God is powerful, but he doesn’t despise anybody; he’s mighty in his power to understand.

6 He doesn’t keep sinners alive, but gives justice to the oppressed.

item.title: Job 37
item.description:
Job Chapter 37

1 My heart pounds when I think about this; it feels like it’s out of place.

2 Listen closely to his thundering, the rumbling that comes from his mouth.

3 He unleashes his lightning under the whole sky; it travels to the horizon in every direction.

4 After it his roars; he thunders with his majestic voice and doesn’t hold anything back.

5 God thunders wondrously and does extraordinary things we can’t comprehend.

item.title: Job 38
item.description:
Job Chapter 38

1 God answered Job out of the whirlwind: 2"Who is this that confuses my counsel with ignorant words?

3 Gird up* like a man; I’ll ask you some questions, and you answer me.

4 Where were you when I laid the foundation for the earth? Tell me if you have any idea.

5 Who specified its measurements or stretched out a line on it? Surely you know!

item.title: Job 39
item.description:
Job Chapter 39

1 Do you know when mountain goats give birth? Do you ever see a deer calving?

2 Can you count the months of their gestation or learn when they have their fawns?

3 They crouch down to deliver their young.

4 Their offspring grow strong out in the open; they leave home and never return. 5"Who turned the wild donkey loose? Who untied its ropes?

6 I gave it the open country for a home, desert land to live in?

item.title: Job 40
item.description:
Job Chapter 40

1 Yahveh said to Job, 2"Will a faultfinder spar with the Almighty? Let the one that argues with God answer that."

3 Job said, 4"I’m insignificant; what kind of answer can I give? I’ve put my hand over my mouth.

5 I’ve spoken once or twice; that’s enough; I don’t have anything else to say."

6 Yahveh answered him out of the storm: 7"Gird up* like a man; I’ll ask you some questions, and you answer me.

item.title: Job 41
item.description:
Job Chapter 41

1 Can you pull Leviathan in on a fishhook or muzzle it with a noose?

2 Can you tie it up with a rope in its nose or pierce its jaw with a hook?

3 Will it beg you for mercy or speak to you softly?

4 Will it agree to work for you like a slave for life?

5 Will you make a pet out of it like a bird or put it on a leash for your little girls?

item.title: Job 42
item.description:
Job Chapter 42

1 Job answered Yahveh: 2"I know you can do anything and nobody can thwart what you do.

3 You asked, ‘Who is this that darkens my counsel with ignorance?’ So I admit I don’t understand; these things are too awesome for me to look into.

4 You said, ‘Listen; I’ll talk; I’ll ask; you instruct me.’

5 I’d only heard about you before, but now I see you.
